awd_titl_txt: Implementation Project: Strengthening Student Success in STEM (S^4)
awd_abstract_narration:
Implementation Projects provide support to Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) to design, implement, study, and assess comprehensive institutional efforts to increase the number of students receiving undergraduate degrees in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) and enhance the quality of their preparation by strengthening STEM education and research. The project at Fayetteville State University seeks to build on previous successful efforts to increase the participation of African-American students in STEM disciplines.  The goal of this project is to significantly improve recruitment, persistence, retention and graduation rates for STEM undergraduate students. 

The project will utilize evidence-based, high-impact pedagogical practices to improve student learning and outcomes. The practices include: a professional seminar course sequence; assessment-based adaptive mathematics courses; student-centered active learning environment upside-down pedagogies; intrusive peer tutoring and supplemental instruction; and undergraduate research. The project will study the impact and efficacy of the flipped classroom and determine effect sizes of its adoption by examining students' perceptions, learning and outcomes. The project will be advised and evaluated for effectiveness by internal and external advisory boards and an evaluator.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The Implementation Project titled Strengthening STEM Student Success (S4) was established at Fayetteville State University with the goal to increase enrollment and degree completion in STEM based on evidence of promise or "what works" initiative of the U.S. Department of Education. The project is based on four tenets, namely, enrollment, persistence, retention and graduation and these were used to define project objectives. Between fall 2016 and fall 2023, enrollment in STEM disciplines increased from 537 to 1,170 students with a yearly average percentage increase of 13%. The enrollment objective was met except for the first two years; a steady increase in STEM enrollment was recorded, yielding over 15% average increase in the last three years. The persistence objective was to decrease the attrition rate to 15% in STEM and it was measured by the percentage of continuing students who did not return in fall semester. The attrition rates of STEM disciplines ranged between 19% and 28% with an average of 24% each year. This is about 2% higher than the attrition rate of the overall institution’s attrition. The retention objective was to increase the first- and second-year retention of first-time freshmen. The second-year retention rates ranged between 57% and 64% with an average of 60% each year. This is about 5% higher than the retention rate of the overall student enrollment in the institution. The graduation objective was measured by the number of degrees conferred in STEM. This number ranged between 78 and 118 in the period 2017-2023. For the 2023-2024 academic year, the number of degrees conferred in STEM was estimated to exceed 255. The yearly average for the same period is 97. This is about 21% increase from the baseline of 80 degrees.

The implementation project used a variety of strategies: Professional Seminar Course Sequence; Assessment-Based Math Course; SCALE-UP Studio Classroom; Intrusive Tutoring and Supplemental Instruction; Undergraduate Research Mentoring; Flipped Learning Pedagogy; and STEM Education Research. The outcomes included:

  • A curriculum revamp of a section of the first-year seminar course to include contents suitable for STEM. This initiative served a total of 177 students between spring 2019 and fall 2020. The University College that hosted the course was reconstituted and that affected its continuation.
  • Retrofitted classroom in the newly completed Science and Technology Building to accommodate the SCALE-UP Studio. The Studio made the implementation of the flipped pedagogy possible.
  • The flipped pedagogy was incorporated into several “gateway” courses (Principles of Biology I, General Chemistry I, General Chemistry II, Introduction to Computer Science for Technical Majors, Introduction to Programming Methodology, Precalculus Mathematics I, College Physics I). A total of 2,766 students were served in all flipped-based courses.
  • The assessment-based Math strategy incorporated a 4-week long enhancement lesson for students enrolled in Pre-Calculus I in the beginning weeks of the semester, after rigorous diagnostic assessment of students. A total of 328 students were served with this initiative.
  • The tutoring initiative involved a variety of approaches (one-on-one, group and drop-in) and on average, 16 tutors participated each year. Approximately 660 tutees were served, and records show that tutees who attended at least 5 tutoring sessions successfully completed the courses for which they were tutored with at least “C” grade.
  • A total of 82 students were mentored by faculty through the research mentoring initiative of the implementation project. Students gained research knowledge in a variety of research topics in STEM. Many of these students have graduated and are either employed in STEM-related workforce or are pursuing graduate education.
  • The STEM education research covered the following: an in-depth analysis of the efficacy of flipped learning and assessment-based math using student’s academic performance and inferential statistics; analysis of students’ perceptions of flipped-based learning pedagogy using surveys and focused interviews; and the study of the impact of flipped-based learning using effect size measurement. The effect size measures the magnitude of an experimental effect. Overall, there were significant gains in students’ academic achievements in flipped-based or assessment-based Math courses. However, it must be noted that there were cases where the traditional (controlled) courses outperformed the flipped-based or assessment-based Math courses. Analyses show that students’ perceptions were mixed. From the use of effect size, the intervention is said to have “low” effect if the effect size is less than or equal to 0.2; “medium” effect if the effect size is between 0.2 and 0.8; and “high” effect of the effect size is greater than or equal to 0.8. Overall, 67% of flipped-based courses had either medium or high effect.

In summary, the supported flipped pedagogy impacted instructors by providing them with new and effective teaching methods and making them more culture aware. Flipped pedagogy increased student engagement through active involvement in their learning. Flipped pedagogy improved student outcomes—students perform better on tests and have higher grades than those in traditional classrooms.

 


Last Modified: 07/17/2024
Modified by: Daniel I Okunbor

A curriculum revamp of a section of the first-year seminar course to include contents suitable for STEM. This initiative served a total of 177 students between spring 2019 and fall 2020. The University College that hosted the course was reconstituted and that affected its continuation.

In summary, the supported flipped pedagogy impacted instructors by providing them with new and effective teaching methods and making them more culture aware. Flipped pedagogy increased student engagement through active involvement in their learning. Flipped pedagogy improved student outcomesstudents perform better on tests and have higher grades than those in traditional classrooms.
